comments.commentBody:
Opinion writers keep writing that Trump should do this, Trump should do that. The thing is Trump doesn't care what's right or wrong. He doesn't understand the presidency, the Constitution, how government works, or history. Furthermore, he doesn't care to learn or understand.
What Trump cares about is Trump and money, money and Trump, and a whole bunch of adoration. The world, equality, the environment, you and me, nothing else matters to Trump if it doesn't make money.

Who knew that the candidate that kept on talking about Crooked Hillary could turn out to be our crookedest president-elect ever?  Actually, tens of millions of American voters did - all the warning signs were there, flashing bright red.  And many of them voted for him anyway.   Between his corrupt character and the CIA's confirmation of Russia's deliberate interference in our election to help him, he will forever be a tainted, illegitimate president.

There's a list a mile long of conflicts of interest, recklessness, disgrace, clear and present danger. Are we going to keep pointing all these things out until there's no point in doing so or are we going to do something about it? This is not a drill.

Maybe we can think of this another way: The more side jobs Trump has the better. The less time he spends governing, the less able he will be to completely destroy the country. Let's get him on a global tour of his properties fast.

"At the very least, he must publish his tax returns and transfer the lease to his Washington hotel to an independent operator."

Is that enough to ensure a clean administration ? No.

Also, since many of his cabinet picks are from the corporate world, they too face the same ethical dilemma -- the symptom just spread from Trump to his cabinet.

Trump must clean this up ... pronto.

The conflicts are bad enough, standing alone. But The Donald's "nonchalance" is worse - it demonstrates the attitude that America's laws, rules, and even our Constitution are mere options for him. That he can ignore all of it on mere personal whim, by declaring in what he perceives as his own unfettered personal authority, "Oh, I don't see a problem. Trust me, I've taken care of everything."

That is the mindset, the ethos, the voice and spirit of a dictator. And THAT is the real problem.

I'm exhausted and sick of this man and his tantrums and tweets. He's totally entitled and runs rough shod over every convention. It isn't productive at all for this country to keep this man as President. He doesn't seem to understand the gravity or honor of the position he got voted into. He's a dilettante without focus or policy. He's filling his cabinet with unsuitable and mainly unqualified rogues. Why on earth was he selected for a presidential candidate with all the financial and family ties baggage he has? And he simply refuses to comply with divesting himself of his wealth. Who will make him comply?

Let's be honest.

None of this matters.

The Times could run a front page article every day about conflict of interest and it wouldn't affect anybody. Not Republicans in Congress, Mr. Trump's voters, or the vast majority of other Americans. It's a one-party government and they'll do what they want.

Why does there even need to be debate about this? Trump needs to remove all conflicts of interest and focus solely on the job of president. This situation highlights just how different the rules for the rich are from those for the rest of us. My job contracts all specify that I must devote all my professional activities to my employer. Moonlighting is not allowed without the approval of my employer and would only be granted where there are clearly no conflict of interests.

iWork for a big 4 accounting firm but not as an auditor. There are very stringent regulations and procedures in place to ensure independence of our opinions. So if I spend 10 hours or more working on a business issues in a company we audit, I have to declare any potential conflicts of interest and divest them immediately. This requirement extends to my spouse, parents and children. So if my husband happens to own a few shares in a company that I want to do a bit of work on, he has to sell them. There's no materiality test. Sell or risk losing your job.

The president may not be officially held to the same standards but until now, all have know that the legitimacy of government depends on holding themselves to the same standards as the rest of us. Trump needs to do the right thing and if he isn't willing to, the Electoral College should not vote for him.

If there is one concept the President-elect knows and values, it is "currency." He has built businesses on generating it, and he knows that any step which stifles that currency generation won't be around long.

Recognizing that he is now in a "new world," it can be expected that the President-elect will value currency of a different medium -- political currency, which will have a strong impact on whether his presidency is a success. And being an active witness to the rapid currency depletion of his predecessor as well as his election opponent, he knows that "sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander; i.e., that his currency could be devalued pretty fast, too, rendering him a political "loser." He knows, only too well, that --quoting the 1970 film, "Patton," --"all glory is fleeting."

So here is to a wise realist -- President-elect Trump -- who will recognize the importance of his political currency as well as avoiding unforced errors that will devalue his own. Finally, he knows that he has but one chance to make a good "first impression" as President, and thus the nation can expect that he'll divest himself of any institutional holding, convert his wealth into cash, and simply turn it over to an independent, blind trust and trustee. And, if he is really smart, he won't involve his kids in the government, paid or unpaid. The nation elected him, not them.
